fulltext:
46
Lily Ross Taylor
assumption that he also postponed the election of tribunes of the plebs.  ' Plebeian officers were chosen on an independent schedule,  and,  since the comitia did not require the taking of the auspices,  they would have been unaffected by the announcement that Bibulus seems to have made to Caesar,  that he would watch the heavens on all comitial days until October i8.  ® There is no evidence after the reforms following the decem - virate that the dioice of plebeian officers was ever postponed.  Instead there is clear proof in various years that tribunes and aediles of the plebs had been chosen when no other magistrates were in office.  ^ In every case for which we have knowledge of dates the plebeian officers were chosen in July.  The two specific dates recorded for the comitia are July 17 in 65 and July 28 in 54.  ® Mommsen is probably right in holding that the elections of plebeian officers were firmly fixed in July.  There is no reason to doubt that the tribunes for 58 were elected in July of 59. 
The Vettius incident,  which took place before the tribunes were elected,  is,  then,  not later than July.  It can be more closely fixed than that.  Vettius' revelations were made first in the senate and then on the following day in a contio before the people.  By the lex Pupia of 61,  meetings of the senate were limited to noncomitial days ®.  In July these days were 1—9,  15,  16,  19,  21,  23—25.  Now we know the events of July 25 from ad Atticum II 21,  and of preceding days from II 20,  which seems to have been written immediately before 21.  I think it safe to conclude that the Vettius affair took place before July 20. 
The terminus post quern for the Vettius affair is the gladiatorial show given by Gabinius,  candidate for the consulship ( 24,  3 ).  From letter 19 it is clear that the show took place not long before the ludi Apollinares,  whidi began on July 6 ; it probably occurred at the end of June or in the first days of July.  The Vettius affair is then to be dated between the beginning of July,  or shortly before,  and July 20.  Letter 24,  with 23,  whidb was written just before it,  is out of order in the collection
2.  Mommsen evidently did not make that assumption ( see note 3 ),  nor did Eduard Meyer,  Caesars Monarchie und das Principat des Pompeius ^ ( Stuttgart and Berlin,  1919 ) 80.  But Meyer ( p.  84 ) dates the Vettius affair after July 25. 
3.  For the evidence see Mommsen,  Staatsredit,  P 585 f ; IP 276 ff. 
4.  That was true both in 53 and in 52.  See also Livy VI 35,  10 ; Dio XLII 20,  4. 
5.  Cic.  ad Alt.  I i,  i ; IV 15,  8.  In 70 and in 51 the tribunes were elected by August first. 
6.  On the lex Pupia see Cic.  ad F am.  I 4,  i ; Q.  Fr.  II 2,  3.  On the date of the law see Niccolini,  I Fasti dei Tribuni della Plebe ( Milan,  1934 ) 257 f. 
7.  It is well known that the first eleven letters of the collection to Atticus and the letters of Books XII and XIII have come down to us in confused order,  and that there are minor dislocations elsewhere.  In an article to appear in Classical Philology for October 1949 I shall try to show that certain letters of Book IV are out of order.
